header_summary:
Jeremy introduces a novel strategy for implementing Bitcoin covenants without altering the native protocol, utilizing covenant emulators and signing servers alongside a BITVM fraud proof system to enforce compliance through financial penalties for violations. This approach and its underlying mechanics are detailed in a paper available at [https://rubin.io/bitcoin/2024/11/26/unfed-covenants/](https://rubin.io/bitcoin/2024/11/26/unfed-covenants/), providing a comprehensive framework for the community.

Antoine Poinsot raises concerns about potential duplicate coinbase transactions within the Bitcoin network and proposes several solutions to distinguish future transactions and prevent the necessity of re-enabling BIP30 verification. This discussion, aimed at soliciting feedback from the mining community, explores modifications to transaction elements and the impact on mining operations, emphasizing the need for compatibility with future technologies like Utreexo nodes. Further details and the invitation for community input are documented at [https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/cLJjA4Em1sfbLHBctwsPUvquk8uMGGnXt2zGx7mn_JNu5F-HULjtdsBQjX9VET6MVRhbzJExPRrwNKBeLV1S30uEgCtFiBmMPVuzTFVNxkY=@protonmail.com](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/cLJjA4Em1sfbLHBctwsPUvquk8uMGGnXt2zGx7mn_JNu5F-HULjtdsBQjX9VET6MVRhbzJExPRrwNKBeLV1S30uEgCtFiBmMPVuzTFVNxkY=@protonmail.com).

Sjors delves into the concept of concurrent validation of competing blocks to enhance blockchain security and efficiency, alongside investigating a benchmark suggesting a 15x performance improvement in Initial Block Download (IBD) times. These discussions highlight innovative strategies and the need for optimization in blockchain protocol design and performance, with insights shared at [https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/can-parallel-validation-side-step-the-slow-block-issue/1288/3](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/can-parallel-validation-side-step-the-slow-block-issue/1288/3) and [https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/libbitcoin-for-core-people/1222/12](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/libbitcoin-for-core-people/1222/12).

Lastly, the Warnet team indicates a commitment to reintegrate Lightning Network support, emphasizing collaboration and effective communication with the development community to ensure alignment with upcoming changes, as discussed at [https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/op-expire-mitigating-replacing-cycling-attacks/1282/5](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/op-expire-mitigating-replacing-cycling-attacks/1282/5). This gesture underscores the collaborative spirit within the Bitcoin development ecosystem, aiming for technological advancements and protocol enhancements.

active_posts.title: ColliderScript: Covenants in Bitcoin via 160-bit hash collisions
active_posts.summary:
- The team introduced a novel Bitcoin covenant creation and spending method, bypassing soft forks using Tapscript.
- Constructing these covenants is straightforward, but spending them demands computational effort exceeding current Bitcoin mining.
- The innovation allows arbitrary computation within Bitcoin transactions up to 4MB, potentially enabling quantum-resistant Lamport signatures.

active_posts.title: Slashing covenants
active_posts.summary:

- The system uses Bitcoin script capabilities and Lamport signatures to verify authenticity without complex cryptography.
- Despite being developed for Bitcoin, its application might be easier on Ethereum due to platform flexibility.
